Description: American lager is light in flavor, color, and alcohol content, and is often produced in large quantities. ABV: 3.2-4.0% IBU: 5-15
Examples: Budweiser, Coors, Pabst Blue Ribbon
Pairing: American cuisine, spicy food

Description: German helles is maltier than a traditional pilsner and features a bright gold color. ABV: 4.8-5.6% IBU:18-25
Examples: Victory Helles Lager, Stoudt's Gold Lager
Pairing: German cuisine, pork, brie

Description: German pilsner is pale gold in color with a medium hop flavor and a slight note of maltiness. ABV: 4.6-5.3% IBU: 25-40
Descriptive Words: pale gold, medium hoppy, light malt
Examples: Tröegs Sunshine Pils, Bavaria, Sierra Nevada's Nooner Pilsner
Pairing: German cuisine, poultry, fish, spicy cheese

Description: Czech or bohemian pilsner is a straw colored beer with a noticeably bitter hop flavor. These beers can sometimes have a floral aroma. ABV: 4.1-5.1% IBU: 30-45
Examples: Lagunita's PILS, Dogfish Head's Piercing Pils
Pairing: Spicy food, Asian cuisine, sharp cheddar cheese

Description: Amber lager features prevalent malt flavors with varying levels of hoppiness. This beer is also characterized by a darker color, caramel aroma, and smooth taste. ABV: 4.8-5.4% IBU: 18-30
Examples: Yuengling Lager, Samuel Adams Boston Lager, Tröegs Nugget Nectar
Pairing: American cuisine, poultry and beef, cheddar

Description: Named for the celebration in Munich, Oktoberfest is a full-bodied beer with a rich, toasted flavor and a dark copper color. ABV: 5.1-6.0% IBU: 18-25
Examples: Samuel Adams Octoberfest, Paulaner Oktoberfest-Märzen, Victory Brewing Company's Festbier
Pairing: German cuisine, meat and vegetables, spicy cheese

Description: Schwarzbier is a dark beer that is surprisingly lighter in flavor. Schwarzbiers are less malty than would be expected, but still boast a slight sweetness. ABV: 3.8-4.9% IBU: 22-30
Descriptive Words: dark color, light flavor, light malty flavor, light sweetness
Examples: Shiner Bohemian Black Lager, Guinness Black Lager
Pairing: German cuisine, spicy food, muenster cheese

Description: Vienna lager is reddish in color with a sweet malty flavor. These beers boast a subtle hop flavor and crisp drinkability. ABV: 4.5-5.5% IBU: 22-28
Descriptive Words: sweet , malty flavor, medium hops, crisp
Examples: Dos Equis Amber Lager, Great Lakes Eliot Ness, Blue Point Toasted Lager
Pairing: German cuisine, Mexican cuisine, pork, spicy cheese

Description: The bock is a malty, sweet beer with a toasty flavor and a dark copper color. ABV: 6.3-7.5% IBU: 20-30
Examples: Samuel Adams Winter Lager, Great Lakes Rockefeller Bock
Pairing: German cuisine, meat and vegetables, chocolate, Camembert cheese

Description: Doppelbocks are stronger than the traditional style and boast a higher alcohol content and a fuller body. ABV: 6.6-7.9% IBU: 17-27
Examples: Tröegs Troegenator Double Bock, Samuel Adams Double Bock, Paulaner Salvator Doppelbock
Pairing: Heavy foods like red meat, pork, or ham, and sharp cheeses

Description: Weizenbocks are wheat bocks and can take on fruity, malty flavors. ABV:7.0-9.5% IBU:15-35
Examples: Victory Brewing Company's Moonglow, Southern Tier Brewing Company's Goat Boy
Pairing: German cuisine, meat and poultry, chocolate

Description: Maibocks are more pale and hoppy than traditional bocks, although the malt flavor is still present. ABV: 6.0-8.0% IBV: 20-38
Examples: Capital Maibock, Hofbräu Maibock, Smuttynose Maibock
Pairing: Italian and German cuisines, fish and shellfish, asiago and swiss cheese

Description: American brown ale is a dark beer without the bitterness of porters and stouts. This style boasts a dark caramel color and a medium to full-bodied profile. ABV: 4.2-6.3% IBU: 25-45
Examples: Brooklyn Brown Ale, Sierra Nevada Tumbler Autumn Brown
Pairing: American cuisine, heavy foods like beef stew, red meat

Description: American amber ale is a malty, medium-bodied beer with a caramel flavor and amber color. ABV: 4.4-6.1% IBU: 25-45
Descriptive Words: malty, medium-bodied, caramel flavor, medium color
Examples: Lagunitas Imperial Red Ale, Stone Brewing Company's Levitation Ale
Pairing: American cuisine, meat, fish, bleu cheese

Description: American pale ale is a medium-bodied beer with a noticable hop flavor and a light copper color. ABV: 4.4-5.4% IBU: 30-50
Examples: Sierra Nevada Brewing Company's Pale Ale, Smuttynose Shoals Pale Ale
Pairing: Fish and seafood, poultry, cheddar cheese

Description: Blonde ales balance the flavors of malt and hops nicely, and they often have a fruity aroma. ABV: 4.1-5.1% IBU: 15-25
Examples: Victory Brewing Company's Summer Love, Flying Fish Brewing Company's Farmhouse Summer Ale
Pairing: Italian cuisine, spicy food, fish, pepper jack cheese

Description: English bitters are named for the bitter flavor that the hops present. They have fruity flavors and lower alcohol content. ABV: 3.0-4.2% IBU: 20-35
Examples: Sharp's Brewery's Doom Bar Bitter, Surly Brewing Company's Bitter Brewer
Pairing: Fried food, fish, feta cheese

Description: Also known as "extra special bitters," English pale ales have a strong hop flavor that is balanced by sweet malt. ABV: 4.5-5.5% IBU: 20-40
Examples: Black Sheep Ale, Flying Fish Extra Pale Ale
Pairing: American and English cuisines, meat, and English cheeses

Description: American IPAs have more hops, big herbal or citrus flavors, and high bitterness compared to pale ale. ABV: 6.3-7.5% IBU: 50-70
Descriptive Words: hoppy, herbal flavor, citrus flavor, bitter
Examples: Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA, Lagunitas IPA, Sierra Nevada Brewing Company's Torpedo Extra IPA
Pairing: American and Indian cuisines, meat, poultry, fish, and gorgonzola cheese

Description: Imperial or Double IPAs are American IPAs, but with a stronger flavor, hop bitterness, and a higher alcohol content. ABV: 7.0-14.0% IBU: 65-100
Examples: Dogfish Head 120 Minute IPA, Russian River Brewing Company's Pliny the Elder, Lagunitas Brewing Company's Maximus
Pairing: American cuisine, meat, fish, and sharp cheddar

Description: English IPAs are similar to the American style, but with a weaker hop flavor and lower alcohol content. ABV: 5.0-7.0% IBU: 35-63
Examples: Goose Island India Pale Ale, Shipyard IPA, Samuel Smith’s India Ale
Pairing: American and Indian cuisines, fish, and parmesan cheese

Description: American imperial porters are dark in color, but lacking in burnt malt taste. They also boast a malty sweetness that goes well with chocolate and coffee. ABV: 7.0-12.0% IBU: 35-50
Examples: Sierra Nevada Brewing Company's Porter, Stone Smoked Porter
Pairing: American cuisine, barbecue, meat, and asiago cheese

Description: English brown porter is a dark beer that's similar to the American style, but usually with a lower alcohol content and less malt sweetness. ABV: 4.5-6.0% IBU: 20-30
Examples: Shipyard Longfellow Winter Ale, Arcadia Brewing Company's Arcadia London Porter
Pairing: American and English cuisines, meat, chocolate, and fontina cheese

Description: Robust porters are stronger and more bitter than a brown porter with a rich dark color and a subtle caramel flavor. ABV: 5.1-6.6% IBU: 25-40
Descriptive Words: strong, bitter, dark color, caramel flavor
Examples: Smuttynose Robust Porter, Thomas Hooker Imperial Porter
Pairing: American and English cuisines, heavy foods like stew and beef, and colby cheese

Description: American stouts are dark beers that feature malt flavors working to create strong chocolate and coffee notes, but without overpowering hop bitterness. ABV: 5.7-8.9% IBU: 35-60
Descriptive Words: dark color, chocolate flavor, coffee flavor, light hoppy
Examples: Highland Black Mocha Stout, Bell's Kalamazoo Stout, Dogfish Head Brewery's Chicory Stout
Pairing: Heavy foods, meat, oysters, chocolate, and brie cheese

Description: American imperial stouts are strong dark beers with a malty flavor and a deep black color. ABV: 7.0-12.0% IBU: 50-80
Examples: Dogfish Head Brewery's Worldwide Stout, Stoudts Fat Dog Imperial Stout, Bell's Java Stout
Pairing: Heavy foods, poultry, aged cheddar

Description: As their name suggests, oatmeal stouts feature oatmeal in their malt blend. This adds smoothness and sweetness to the beer. ABV: 3.8-6.0% IBU: 20-40
Examples: Young's Oatmeal Stout, Rogue Ales' Shakespeare Oatmeal Stout, Tröegs Java Head Stout
Pairing: Meat, shellfish, chocolate, camembert cheese

Description: Lactose sugar adds a sweet caramel or chocolate flavor to milk stouts. ABV: 4.0-7.0% IBU: 15-25
Examples: Young's Double Chocolate Stout, Lancaster Brewing Company's Milk Stout, Samuel Adams Cream Stout
Pairing: Mexican cuisine, beef, chocolate, ice cream, and cheddar or goat cheese

Description: Irish dry stouts are dark beers; black in color with a bitterness that comes from roasted barley. ABV: 3.8-5.0% IBU: 30-40
Examples: Guinness Draught, Murphy's Irish Stout, Beamish Irish Stout
Pairing: Heavy food like beef and stew, barbecue, burgers

Description: Belgian pale ale contains a toasted malt flavor that is subtle enough to not overpower the taste of the hops. ABV: 4.0-6.0% IBU: 20-30
Examples: Leffe Blonde, Weyerbacher Brewing Company's Verboten, Samuel Adams Belgian Session
Pairing: American cuisine, fried food, fish, salad, and tangy cheeses

Description: Belgian dubbels feature rich and malty flavor with a spicy, fruity note. ABV: 6.3-7.6% IBU: 20-35
Examples: Chimay Premiere, Blue Moon Winter Abbey Ale, Flying Fish Abbey Dubbel
Pairing: American cuisine, barbecue, meat, and Limburger cheese

Description: Belgian trippels are lighter-bodied beers with a slight hoppy bitterness and a high alcohol content. ABV: 7.1-10.1% IBU: 20-45
Examples: Victory Brewing Company's Golden Monkey, Weyerbacher Brewing Company's Merry Monks
Pairing: Pasta dishes, meat, poultry, gouda cheese

Description: Belgian quadrupels are dark brown, full-bodied beers that exhibit flavors like brown sugar and fruit. They also have a very high alcohol content. ABV: 7.2-11.2% IBU: 25-50
Descriptive Words: dark color, full-bodied, brown sugar, fruity
Examples: Weyerbacher Brewing Company's QUAD, Brewery Ommegang Three Philosophers
Pairing: Smoked meat, goose, brie cheese

Description: Belgian strong dark ale features a very high alcohol content with complex fruity flavors. ABV: 7.0-15.0% IBU: 20-50
Examples: Tröegs Mad Elf, Bell's Brewery's Hell Hath No Fury Ale, Dogfish Head Brewery's Raison D'Être
Pairing: American cuisine, barbecue, blue cheese

Description: Saisons (also known as farmhouse ales) have earthy notes and a medium hop flavor. ABV: 4.4-6.8% IBU: 20-38
Examples: Samuel Adams Rustic Saison, Dogfish Head Brewery's Noble Rot, Victory Brewing Company's Helios
Pairing: Indian and Asian cuisine, poultry, seafood, and parmesan cheese

Description: American pale wheat beer is pale in color, lower in alcohol content, and with a light bready flavor. ABV: 3.5-5.6% IBU: 10-35
Examples: Blue Moon Summer Honey Wheat, Samuel Adams Coastal Wheat, Shipyard Summer Ale
Pairing: Mexican cuisine, spicy food, poultry, and mozzarella cheese

Description: Witbier gets its name from its white color, and has a light, fruity flavor to match. ABV: 4.8-5.6% IBU: 10-17
Examples: Hoegaarden White Ale, Dogfish Head Brewery's Namaste, Blue Moon Belgian White, Victory Brewing Company's Whirlwind Witbier
Pairing: Seafood, poultry, pork, salad, and soft cheeses

Description: Berliner Weisse is tart, sour beer with a pale color. Sometimes raspberry syrup is added to dull the sour taste. ABV: 2.8-3.4% IBU: 3-6
Examples: Dogfish Head's Festina Peche, Freetail Brewing Company's Yo Soy Un Berliner, Iron Hill Brewery's Berliner Weisse
Pairing: German Cuisine, ham, salad, and soft cheeses

Description: Dunkelweizen is a darker version of a Hefeweizen. These beers have a malty flavor with hints of banana. ABV: 4.8-5.4% IBU: 10-15
Examples: Samuel Adams Dunkelweizen, Franziskaner Hefe-Weisse Dunkel
Pairing: German and Indian cuisines, fish, and goat cheese

Description: Hefeweizen is a light colored wheat beer with a crisp taste that can sometimes have hints of cloves or apples. ABV: 4.9-5.6% IBU: 10-15
Examples: Sierra Nevada Kellerweis Hefeweizen, Pennsylvania Brewing Company's Penn Weizen
Pairing: German cuisine, seafood, fish, and brick cheeses

Description: American sour beer packs a wild punch from certain bacteria that are introduced during the fermentation process. ABV: Varies IBU: Varies
Examples: Samuel Adams American Kriek, Weyerbacher Brewing Company's Riserva, Jolly Pumpkin Artisan Ales' La Roja
Pairing: Fruit and strong cheese

Description: Belgian fruit lambics are brewed with fruit to make an intense sweet and sour flavor. ABV: 5.0-8.9% IBU: 15-21
Examples: Upland Brewing Company's Raspberry Lambic, Dogfish Head Brewery's Festina Lente
Pairing: Fruit, salad, chocolate, and soft cheese

Description: Flanders red ale evokes a malty, fruity flavor underneath a strong sour taste brought on by Lactobacillus bacteria during fermentation. ABV: 4.8-6.6% IBU: 5-18
Examples: New Belgium Lips of Faith La Folie, The Lost Abbey's Red Poppy Ale
Pairing: Meat, blue cheese, and cheddar cheese

Description: Gueuzes are aged beers that give off a very strong sour flavor. ABV: 6.2-8.1% IBU: 9-23
Examples: Brouwerij Boon's Boon Gueuze, The Bruery's Rueuze
Pairing: Strong cheeses

Description: Pumpkin beer is brewed with fresh pumpkin and common fall spices. These beers are increasingly popular, and can be made with lagers, ales, and sour beers. ABV: 2.3-5.0% IBU: 5-70
Examples: Elysian Brewing Company’s Night Owl Pumpkin Ale, Weyerbacher Brewing Company’s Imperial Pumpkin Ale, Samuel Adams Harvest Pumpkin Ale, Smuttynose Pumpkin Ale
Pairing: Poultry, soft creamy cheeses

Description: Rye beer often features malty, roasted flavors, with lower hop bitterness. Rye beers can be made as ales or as lagers, and will either take on a sweet or spicy flavor. ABV: Varies IBU: Varies
Examples: Founders Red’s Rye IPA, Great Lakes’ Rye of the Tiger IPA, The Bruery’s Sour in the Rye
Pairing: Spicy meat, creamy cheese

Description: Smoke beer is any beer that is brewed with malt that has been kilned over an open fire. The smoke adds a noticeable, but not overpowering flavor, which is inspired by traditional German rauchbier. ABV: Varies IBU: Varies
Examples: Ithaca Beer Company's Gorges Smoked Porter, Goose Island Beer Company’s Prairie Smoke, Denver Beer Company’s Smoked Lager
Pairing: Roasted vegetables, hard cheese
